CARDINAL . The applicant denied the charges and appealed against ORG judgment . He argued , inter alia , that he had not been given access to all the information gathered as a result of the application of the surveillance measures , and that this had violated the principle of the equality of arms and his defence rights . He further complained about the confusion in the dates and numbers of the authorisations for the application of the surveillance measures . The court had been presented – outside the hearings DATE with CARDINAL prosecutor ’s authorisations dated CARDINAL and DATE which had apparently borne the same number .

CARDINAL . In respect of the authorisation given on DATE by the President of ORG , the applicant noted that it had been for CARDINAL days’ surveillance and had remained valid until DATE . He pointed out that audio recordings had been made on the basis of that authorisation on DATE and DATE . As the applicant had not been given access to the totality of the information gathered as a result of the application of the surveillance measures , it had been impossible to establish whether the application of the measures in question had in fact been limited to the authorised DATE . He pointed out that the period between the first ( DATE ) and the last ( DATE ) undercover recording had been DATE . ORG had only noted that it had had no grounds to doubt that the surveillance authorisation had been lawful but it had not given an opinion in its judgment on the lawfulness of the surveillance activities , namely whether the authorised DATE period had been exceeded .
CARDINAL . The applicant also reiterated his concern that PERSON had acted in the interests and under the guidance of the police .

CARDINAL . The prosecutor argued that the court had examined the lawfulness of the evidence obtained with the use of the surveillance measures by all means at its disposal and pointed out that pursuant to LAW the court had had the ability to examine information obtained through surveillance if it so wished . Therefore , the applicant ’s argument that the judge had examined the surveillance activities outside the hearings was inappropriate : the court had fulfilled its tasks and had demonstrated an appropriate level of interest in the information related to the criminal case .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld ORG judgment . It considered that the applicant ’s conviction was in any event safe , even if the evidence challenged by the defence was set aside .

CARDINAL . ORG found that there were no convincing reasons to think that PERSON had co - operated with the police ; the fact that he had been charged with an offence rather confirmed that the police had received information from third parties , in whose interest it was that parts of the surveillance information were kept secret . ORG found that the applicant ’s right to an adversarial trial had not been infringed owing to the fact that the prosecutor – but not the defence – had had access to the totality of the information gathered with the use of surveillance measures . It considered that there was no reason to overload the criminal case file with irrelevant information . The rights of the defence had not been violated in so far as the prosecutor had not adduced the information in question as evidence against the applicant . Nor had ORG relied on evidence that had not been examined at court hearings .

CARDINAL . In a situation where ORG had examined the lawfulness of the evidence obtained on the basis of LAW outside the hearings , ORG considered that the worthiness and integrity of ORG had to be presumed . Pursuant to LAW , judges had access to ORG secrets . ORG had not examined the surveillance materials secretly ; rather , it had subsequently recorded its examination in a record of a court hearing .

CARDINAL . ORG was satisfied that ORG had examined the surveillance authorisations . For its part , it analysed at length the content of the authorisations and the surveillance activities carried out on their basis and held that there could be no doubt that the surveillance authorisations had been given retroactively . It further found that since no surveillance activities had been carried out on the basis of the authorisation of DATE and since the authorisation had not been used as evidence , there had been no reason to admit that authorisation to the case file .

CARDINAL . In his subsequent appeal to ORG the applicant noted , inter alia , that he had been unaware during the proceedings before ORG that , between the public hearings , the court had examined not only the surveillance authorisations but also the other surveillance materials . He argued that if this had been the case ( as asserted by the prosecutor in ORG and stated in ORG judgment ) , the requirements of a public hearing and an adversarial trial had been breached .

CARDINAL . In her reply to the applicant ’s appeal , the prosecutor , inter alia , explicitly stated that in the present case the judge of ORG had examined the surveillance authorisations and the surveillance file .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG declined to hear the applicant ’s appeal .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Code of Criminal Procedure ( ORG seadustik ) provides that information obtained by surveillance activities is admissible evidence if such information has been obtained in compliance with the requirements of law .

CARDINAL . Pursuant to LAW , a surveillance authorisation ( jälitustoimingu luba ) may be given by a preliminary investigation judge or a prosecutor , depending on the type of surveillance activity in question .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Code provides that a surveillance report shall contain , inter alia , information obtained through the application of the surveillance measures . Photographs , films , audio and video recordings are to be annexed to the report if necessary .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Code concerns covert surveillance and Article CARDINAL deals with wiretapping , covert interception and observation of information . Both ORG stipulate that information obtained through the application of the relevant surveillance measures shall be entered in the surveillance report in so far as necessary for the adjudication of the criminal case ( LAW and LAW , respectively ) .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the LAW provides that at the request of the person concerned , he or she is to be permitted to examine the materials of the surveillance activities conducted with regard to him or her . Nevertheless , in certain cases such information can be withheld with the permission of the prosecutor . Such cases include , inter alia , instances where : the information concerns the private lives of other persons ; its disclosure may damage the rights and freedoms of other persons ; it concerns ORG secrets ; its disclosure may endanger the life , health , honour , dignity or property of an employee of a surveillance agency , of a person who has been engaged in surveillance activities or who has been recruited for surveillance activities , or the confidentiality of the latter ’s co - operation with a surveillance agency ; or where disclosure may prejudice criminal proceedings or give rise to a criminal offence . Information can also be withheld if it can not be separated or disclosed without the information referred to above becoming evident .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW ( NORP seadus ) obliges surveillance agencies to protect persons involved in surveillance activities and , inter alia , ensure the secrecy of their co - operation .
CARDINAL . Section DATE ) of LAW stipulates that information collected in the course of surveillance proceedings shall be stored in a surveillance file ( jälitustoimik ) .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW provides that the use of surveillance information as evidence in a criminal case must not bring about disclosure of the secret surveillance information or the identity of persons who have been engaged in surveillance activities or recruited therefore without their consent .

CARDINAL . Pursuant to section PERSON ) of LAW a person ’s right to examine the materials concerning the surveillance activities carried out in respect of him or her can be restricted on grounds similar to those provided for in LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW provides that everyone may file a complaint with the head of a surveillance agency or its superior agency or with ORG against the activities of the surveillance agency upon the conduct of surveillance activities . Furthermore , everyone has the right of recourse to a court if his or her rights and freedoms have been violated by surveillance activity .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL - CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW ( ORG seadus ) , as in force at the material time , provided that information collected by surveillance agencies on the basis of ORG CARDINAL to CARDINAL of the Code of Criminal Procedure , and the methods , tactics and technical equipment used for collection thereof to the extent to which such information could be used as evidence , were ORG secrets classified as “ restricted ” .
CARDINAL . Pursuant to section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) of the State Secrets Act judges had the right of access to ORG secrets .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW provided that participants in criminal proceedings had the right of access to ORG secrets classified as “ restricted ” , “ confidential ” or “ secret ” , on the basis of a reasoned order of a preliminary investigator or prosecutor or a court ruling , if access was unavoidably necessary for the adjudication of the criminal case . Access could not be granted if this jeopardised the performance of the duties of protection and secrecy provided for in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) and to ORG secrets classified as “ top secret ” .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ( case no . CARDINAL - CARDINAL - CARDINAL - CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) ORG noted that it proceeded unequivocally from LAW that any violation in collecting information through surveillance excluded the admissibility of such information as evidence .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE ( case no . CARDINAL - CARDINAL - CARDINAL - CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) ORG reiterated that any violation in the process of collecting evidence through the application of surveillance measures automatically resulted in the inadmissibility of such information as evidence . It held that all parties to court proceedings had to be able to verify whether LAW had been complied with . Thus , upon the receipt of a request of a party for the assessment of the legality of a surveillance activity , the court was obliged to verify the existence of an authorisation by a court or ORG , and identify whether the information used as evidence had indeed been obtained in the course of the authorised activity and during the authorised period . ORG noted that when determining the legality of surveillance , the court had to ensure the protection of the ORG secret which served as the reason for the prohibition of disclosure of the materials of the surveillance file at a court hearing . However , the court could disclose its opinion on the lawfulness of the surveillance . The disclosure of the court ’s opinion in this regard to the parties had to be recorded in the record of the hearing and , if necessary , in the judgment .
